thread.title: Farage: Trump Helped Usher In A Global Revolution That Will Not Be Stopped
thread.title_full: Farage: Trump Helped Usher In A Global Revolution That Will Not Be Stopped

author: Jack Davis
title: Farage: Trump Helped Usher In A Global Revolution That Will Not Be Stopped

organizations.name: longtime fox news host alan colmes

text:
Farage: Trump Helped Usher In A Global Revolution That Will Not Be Stopped "... he is restoring faith in the democratic process ..." by Jack Davis February 25, 2017 at 3:22pm Share on Facebook 644 Tweet Email Email Print Advertisement - story continues below 
President Donald Trump was a light-bearer in the year a long-overdue revolution began sweeping through the West, Brexit architect Nigel Farage said Friday during his speech at the Conservative Political Action Conference. 
âWhen, in years to come, the generations that follow us study the history of this period, there is one year that will stand out. There is one year that every school child will know and that year is the year of 2016,â Farage told conservatives. 
âBecause in 2016 we witnessed the beginning of a global political revolution and it is one that is not going to stop and it is one that is going to roll out across the rest of the free world,â he said. Advertisement - story continues below 
— Vote Trump Pics (@VoteTrumpPics) February 25, 2017 
â2016 is the year the nation-state democracy made a comeback against the globalists and those who would wish to destroy everything we have ever been,” he added. 
Farage told the conference one of his proudest moments of 2016 was the day in Mississippi when he publicly supported Trump. Advertisement - story continues below 
However, his favorite moment of the year, he said, came on America’s election day. 
“My favorite part of 2016 was watching the faces of the CNN presenters,” he said. âThey are in deep denial.Â They would like to wind the clock back to 2015 to pretend that none of this ever happened.” 
Farage then turned to the future. Advertisement - story continues below Longtime Fox News Host Alan Colmes Dies At 66 
“But just as Brexit becomes more popular by the day, President Trump will become more popular in America by the day,” he said. 
Farage noted that Trump the president is seeking to do something even more remarkable than Trump the candidate. 
” What Iâm seeing, 36 days into the Trump presidency, Iâm seeing something quite remarkable. Iâm seeing an elected leader who is trying to put in place the platform on which he was elected! How about that?” Farage said. “What Trump is doing, by trying to put in place that ticket on which he was elected, he is restoring faith in the democratic process, and good for him.” 
Farage also took the occasion to note that Brexit might never have been passed without President Barack Obama’s British visit in which he told Britons they should not leave the European Union. 
“I will, until my dying day, be grateful that President Obama came to my country, intervened in the referendum, and told the United Kingdom, told America’s greatest friend in the world, that if we chose independence we would go to the back of the line,” he said. 
Farage also affirmed his opposition to globalism and noted there are three things that define the true allies his nation has in the world. 
âOur real friends in the world speak English , have common law and stand by us in times of crisis,â he added. 
Farage noted the movement against globalism must not be perceived in a negative light. 
“Weâve got to be clear: Weâre not against anybody based on religion or ethnicity. Weâre not against anybody. But weâre for ourselves, weâre for our country, weâre for our communities, weâre for making our people safe and with less risk from global terror! That is what weâre for! And weâre for our country! And weâre for our people! And we are winning!â he said. 
Prior to the speech, Farage talked to The Guardian about Trump’s executive order on travel and immigration. 
âI just donât get the hypocrisy of all you people. Sixteen countries ban (Israelis) going into them, you donât say a dicky bird. This man says for 90 days heâs going to put a temporary suspension on while he looks at the vetting rules —Â and by the way, Americaâs vetting rules are quite strict already, interestingly —Â working out whether itâs right or not, and itâs being portrayed amongst elements in the media and by many in Western politics as if itâs some sort of road to fascism or something awful,” Farage said. 
âI just frankly think itâs the most massively over-the-top reaction. Now obviously heâs got caught up in legal complexity; heâs going to come back and have another try,â he added. What do you think? Scroll down to comment below. Advertisement Popular Right Now
